Situation1: They notice a small discrepancy in the register but it doesn’t affect the total sales for the day.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story:
I stand behind the register, counting bills and coins, when I notice a small discrepancy—just a few cents off. Store policy is clear: every cent must be accounted for, no matter how minor. My manager expects me to report even the smallest error, but I know it won’t affect the total sales for the day. I hesitate, feeling the weight of responsibility pressing on me.

Later, at a communal event, I scan the buffet table. The food looks delicious, but none of the dishes have kosher certification. My friends urge me to join in, and I feel their eyes on me, expecting me to be part of the celebration. Substituting food would be awkward and draw attention, but eating non-kosher goes against everything I’ve been taught.

Both roles tug at me—one demanding strict adherence to rules, the other asking for flexibility in the name of community and belonging. My mind races, torn between the expectations of my job and my faith, wondering which part of myself I’ll have to compromise.
